subject: Re: Media Collective Initiative

triggerMessage.subject: Re: Media Collective Initiative
triggerMessage.body:
Hey Creator,

Thanks for reaching out to R√òDE! We're excited to connect with you and
can‚Äôt wait to see the incredible content you‚Äôll create using our
top-of-the-line microphones and audio gear. Trusted by professionals,
artists, and creators around the world, we‚Äôre here to support your creative
journey.

Whether you decide to produce a full video about R√òDE or include a brief
brand integration, the choice is entirely up to you. We value your creative
freedom and want you to make the content in your own unique style.

Just a quick reminder: The gear is yours to keep at no cost, and we‚Äôll also
compensate you for creating and sharing content that features our products.

Here‚Äôs how to get started:

Visit  https://rodecommunity.com , choose the gear that works best for your
project, and fill out the form with your shipping details.

After reviewing your request, one of our campaign managers will contact you
to confirm your gear selection, discuss your rates, and go over the
specifics of your video. You'll also have the opportunity to share your
rate card and finalize the payment details.

We‚Äôre excited to see your creativity in action and are thrilled to be part
of your content creation!

Looking forward to collaborating,
The R√òDE Team

 Upon review, please know that email you have received is all about Gmail's Increase sending volume slowly, you can check more information to this link: https://support.google.com/a/answer/81126?visit_id=639046947236143096-3487243531&p=UnsolicitedRateLimitError&rd=2#increase-volume-slowly. As for how you can proceed, I‚Äôd recommend using a different email address for now. Thank you for waiting. I checked the logs and noticed that some of your emails were deferred, which is why Gmail sent that warning. This usually happens when there‚Äôs a sudden spike in the number of recipients. 
 
 Looking at your account, the last time you sent to over 45K recipients was back in the first week of December. Don‚Äôt worry, deferrals are temporary, and the messages should go through eventually. 
 
 We highly recommend checking out this guide to help improve your deliverability and avoid any issues like this in the future: Email Sending Frequency and Volume 
 
 Meanwhile, let me know if you have any other questions.

Hey there!

Just wanted to quickly follow up in case our last note got buried.

We‚Äôre launching a major upgrade to the Lovable
<https://lovable.link/hayley> agent
next week and are finalizing a small group of creators to get early access
and publish YouTube content around the launch. Videos are planned to go
live *starting* *next Wednesday through the following week*, so we‚Äôre
locking things down pretty quickly here.

If you‚Äôre interested, feel free to send over your media kit and rates ‚Äî or
we're happy to jump on a quick call if you‚Äôd like a technical overview
first.

Either way, appreciate your time!

Best,
Hayley

triggerMessage.body:
Hi Matt Pocock team,

Hope all is well! I'm Daina from Oxylabs, the world's leading web data
scraping provider. Would you be interested in a potential collaboration
between us and your YouTube channel?

I'm looking for a passionate content creator that can launch a dedicated
YouTube video and showcase what to do with the scraped web data (e.g., feed
it to AI workflows or build apps) that's collected with Oxylabs Web Scraper
API. Various data types are possible: e-commerce results (e.g., Amazon),
real estate listings, search results (e.g., Google) etc. Oxylabs covers IPs
in 195 countries and is compatible with popular software (including n8n),
so it can be used both by developers and those with no coding experience.

Would your audience find the above interesting? If so, could you please let
me know your audience demographics and your rate?

Please let me know your thoughts!

Thanks,

Daina Siauciunaite

triggerMessage.subject: Sponsorship Inquiry: Dedicated Video for Verdent (Parallel AI Agents)
triggerMessage.body:
Hi,

I‚Äôm reaching out from Verdent¬†(verdent.ai<https://www.verdent.ai/>) to discuss a potential sponsorship for your channel. We believe your audience of developers would value a tool built specifically for parallel execution.

The Product:¬†Verdent is an AI coding tool optimized for¬†parallel multitasking, designed to complete complex projects 10x faster.
Parallel Execution:¬†Deploy multiple AI agents to handle different parts of a project simultaneously.
Context Preservation:¬†Switch between tasks seamlessly with full context preserved in the Standalone App.
Isolated Worktrees:¬†Experiment freely in clean, independent workspaces.
Workflow:¬†Transparent "Plan‚ÜíCode‚ÜíVerify" steps in VS Code for error-free results.

The Scope:
Format: Dedicated YouTube video (<10 mins) showcasing real workflows/Tiktok video/IG reels
Content:¬†You are encouraged to compare Verdent with other "vibe coding" tools.
Timeline:¬†Video to go live between Feb 9 ‚Äì Feb 15.

Deliverables:¬†Script and video draft will be required for review prior to the live date.
Budget:¬†This is a paid collaboration. We are open to negotiating the budget based on your channel‚Äôs performance and production quality.
Next Steps:¬†If this aligns with your content schedule, please let us know your rate card¬†or a quote for a dedicated video. We‚Äôd be happy to discuss how we can make this work for you.

Best regards,
Evelyn
Verdent Team
Tec-do Agency

subject: Re: Media Collaboration Effort Plan

triggerMessage.subject: Re: Media Collaboration Effort Plan
triggerMessage.body:
Hey Creator,

Thanks for reaching out to R√òDE! We're excited to connect with you and
can‚Äôt wait to see the incredible content you‚Äôll create using our
top-of-the-line microphones and audio gear. Trusted by professionals,
artists, and creators around the world, we‚Äôre here to support your creative
journey.

Whether you decide to produce a full video about R√òDE or include a brief
brand integration, the choice is entirely up to you. We value your creative
freedom and want you to make the content in your own unique style.

Just a quick reminder: The gear is yours to keep at no cost, and we‚Äôll also
compensate you for creating and sharing content that features our products.

Here‚Äôs how to get started:

Visit  https://rodecommunity.com , choose the gear that works best for your
project, and fill out the form with your shipping details.

After reviewing your request, one of our campaign managers will contact you
to confirm your gear selection, discuss your rates, and go over the
specifics of your video. You'll also have the opportunity to share your
rate card and finalize the payment details.

We‚Äôre excited to see your creativity in action and are thrilled to be part
of your content creation!

Looking forward to collaborating,
The R√òDE Team

triggerMessage.subject: Paid collabs live on Aha this week
triggerMessage.body:
Hey Matt,

I hope this message finds you well.

Hope you're doing great! I'm Francis from Aha (formerly Head AI), an creator agency connecting creators with top campaigns worldwide. We're currently coordinating several collaboration opportunities that align well with your content, so I've combined them below for your convenience.

1. Storm MCP
Streamline your AI workflow with Storm MCP: a secure, enterprise-grade gateway that unifies LLMs, RAG data, and tools‚Äîseamless integration, real-time observability, and robust security.

Hey Matt Pocock,

My name is Zan and I am an influencer campaign manager with Beluga.


I‚Äôm reaching out because I‚Äôm working with Codebuff, an open source alternative to Claude Code, to introduce it to creators like yourself who have an audience that may find it appealing.¬†We would love to know if you would be interested in a paid YouTube video opportunity about Codebuff (we're open to other platforms as well).

Codebuff recently released a new version which provides a 3x speedup and better performance as judged by GPT-5 and Gemini 3 when compared to the same task performed on Claude Code. See here for more details: https://x.com/jahooma/status/2010834935985185242.


The deliverables would entail:


 * 1 x Dedicated video or 1 x Integration in one of your YouTube videos¬†
 * Published any day between January 26 - February 11
 * 1 tracking link in the description with a code giving your audience additional free credits
   

I'm currently scoping interest for this campaign, and would love to learn more about your rates if you are open to sharing that information.¬†


I would greatly appreciate if you could give me a reply by Tuesday (January 20). Thank you!

Best,
Zan¬†(discord: zan.zan.zan.zan)

subject: Re: A quick question...

triggerMessage.subject: Re: A quick question...
triggerMessage.body:
Hi Matt and team,

Massive fan of your work. Despite what some say in the YouTube and X comments I have really appreciated your pivot with AI Hero and the content you have been putting out. It makes sense given the context of what it currently means to be a software developer in my opinion, and the stuff you‚Äôve put out already about Typescript should keep most people including myself occupied for a while. 

I think despite the limitations of the transformer approach to LLMs etc, it‚Äôs evident that there is genuine utility in these models. Your recent video about using plan mode extensively and the tips from that have genuinely made a tremendous difference in the way I work. 

It is giving me more trust in what an LLM is putting out because of that initial planning/exchange. In the past I‚Äôve just given a series of prompts and Claude et al have basically ripped through with varying levels of success, so I had been feeling a bit bummed out despite the Opus hype until recently. 

Things like this I would love to learn more about!

Kind regards,
Tom

Hey Matt, 



I recently read that you‚Äòre now making this newsletter mainly about Ralph/Claude Code. Those are also the most interesting topics about AI for me.



I‚Äòm currently building workflows and agents for clients, which is super fun!

One area where I‚Äôm still learning is how to best leverage CC/Ralph when launching a brand new SaaS product from scratch, especially from a marketing and distribution perspective. subject: Re: Paid opportunity: dedicated YouTube video with InsForge

triggerMessage.subject: Paid opportunity: dedicated YouTube video with InsForge
triggerMessage.body:
Hi,

I am Sam, I lead partnerships at InsForge.

InsForge <https://insforge.dev/> is an AI native backend platform built for
developers building with AI coding agents like Cursor and Claude Code.
Think of it as a backend platform like Supabase, but designed for coding
agents so the backend can be provisioned and operated directly by AI.

We would love to explore a paid dedicated YouTube video with you. Ideally
we would like to publish in the next 2 to 3 weeks, but happy to work around
your schedule if needed.

Attached is a short creative brief with more details. Let me know if you
have any questions, also happy to jump on a call if you'd like.

If this sounds interesting, could you share your pricing for 1 dedicated
video on your YouTube channel.

Best,

Sam Liu

Head of Partnerships at InsForge
[image: image.png]

Hi Matt,

I hope this message finds you well! I‚Äôve been following your content on
*YouTube **@mattpocockuk*, and I really love the unique vibe and creativity
you bring to your videos.

I‚Äôm reaching out on behalf of* Volter AI* to invite you to join our UGC
team. We‚Äôre excited to introduce *Portable.dev*, an innovative AI
development environment for mobile devices, featuring full GitHub
integration.
We‚Äôre looking for creators to produce engaging short-form content about our
platform. We offer competitive compensation, paying per 1k views, so it‚Äôs a
fantastic opportunity to collaborate and earn. If this sounds interesting
to you, I‚Äôd love to connect you with our ops manager to provide more
details and give you access to the platform for a hands-on experience.

Looking forward to the possibility of working together!

subject: Re: A quick question...

triggerMessage.subject: Re: A quick question...
triggerMessage.body:
Hi, Matt.

The thing that interests me the most with AI is exactly how to harness what
AI is supposed to be good at, while ensuring output is accurate,
deterministic, and consistently repeatable.

Being able to do this at scale from plans/tasks (from sprints) using
subagents, then validate and verify outputs still feels out of touch for me.

I "know" the rough idea of what is needed, but actually getting a fully
fleshed working example feels like a few obstacles too many.

I've learned a lot from reading your tweets and articles, but it's gluing
it all together that evades me.


Kind regards,
Chris Sparshott

subject: Re: YouTube Partnership || Open Claude CoWork

triggerMessage.subject: YouTube Partnership || Open Claude CoWork
triggerMessage.body:
Hey Matt Pocock team,

Really enjoyed your recent videos. Your breakdown of AI tools and how to
use them best is always spot on.

I'm reaching out from Composio <https://composio.dev/> about a partnership
opportunity around the Cowork launch.

As you know, Cowork is trending. We recently shipped *Open **Claude CoWork
(*https://github.com/ComposioHQ/open-claude-cowork*)*, an open-source take
on Claude Code. Most existing implementations (including others in OSS) are
essentially GUI or browser-based wrappers that automate tasks locally or
rely on browser automation for SaaS apps ‚Äî which gets slow and brittle.

What makes Co-Work different is that it comes *natively integrated with
800+ APIs* as composio manages the auth on backend. This means users can
not only automate desktop tasks, but actually complete real knowledge work
across tools like Linear, Slack, Jira, GitHub, etc. fast.

We‚Äôd love to collaborate on a dedicated video where you walk through
Co-Work and, in the process, explore why deep, API-level integrations
matter for agentic workflows.

The project‚Äôs getting strong organic traction already ‚Äî Julian Goldie and
Tom Doerr have both shared it recently ‚Äî and momentum is picking up
quickly. I have attached some example demos of its capabilities. Do you
think this will be a fit for your audience?

Would love to do a dedicated video this week.
Best,
Audery Graham
Composio <https://composio.dev/>

This is a module system issue, not a version problem. Your compiled JavaScript has export statements, but browsers need a module-aware script tag to understand them.
In your HTML file, change:
<script src="example.js"></script>
To:
<script type="module" src="example.js"></script>
The type="module" tells the browser to treat the file as an ES module, which supports import/export syntax.
If that doesn't match what the lesson expects, the alternative is changing your TypeScript compiler settings to output a different module format (like CommonJS or a bundled file), but adding type="module" to the script tag is the typical fix here.

subject: Re: A quick question...

triggerMessage.subject: Re: A quick question...
triggerMessage.body:
Hi Matt,

I am a Software Engineering Manager so I like to orchestrate and delegate
to AI like I would a team of engineers. I treat AI less like a chatbot and
more like a programmable collaborator. Lately, I've been trying to build a
system that produces reliable work on demand using specially designed
prompts, workflows, phase gates, and verifiable iteration loops. Since I'm
a hands-on learner, I've been building small, custom CLI tools with Effect
that I can compose together into reusable systems I use daily.

I'm interested in learning more about: controllability, repeatability, and
compounding leverage. What I want to learn the most: how to use Effect to
make AI outputs trustworthy enough to integrate into serious engineering
workflows without constant babysitting.

Thanks,
Urban

triggerMessage.body:
Hello!

I hope this email finds you well :)

I'm Katie from GrowMaxValue Agency, contacting you on behalf of our client
ReaddyAI to discuss potential collaboration opportunities!

ReaddyAI - One-click landing page generation ‚Äî Convenient application
development. Create and share the software you want online, without
coding.  It helps freelancers and small business owners reduce maintenance
stress and improve efficiency, offering a smarter online presence with
real-time support and automation.

I‚Äôve been impressed byyour creativity and the unique way you interact with
your audience on your channel, and I believe you're a perfect fit for this
AI tool! ü§©ü§©

Expected DeliverablesÔºö
1. Platform: 1 x Dedicated or Integrated YouTube video (adjustable to your
liking)
2. Usage: 1-month usage rights
3. Budget: please let me know the price you have in mind!
4. Live date: Before January 30th

Here are some good casesÔºö
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=19-I3OaAGkY&t=32s
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cgZB0_ghQsA

We‚Äôd love to hear back from you soon, as this campaign will only run for
two month! üíï

Kindest,
Katie
Agency Manager

subject: Re: Matt Pocock X Outskill: Paid Sponsorship

triggerMessage.subject: Matt Pocock X Outskill: Paid Sponsorship
triggerMessage.body:
Hey ,

I am Sheel, Partnerships Manager at Outskill - World‚Äôs first AI-Focused
Educational Platform - and I've been following your Youtube channel for a
while now.
I truly appreciate your content, and I am a huge fan of your work.

Over the past 2+ years, We‚Äôve done 500+partnerships with the biggest
youtubers like Caspian Report, AI Revolution, Investing Simplified, Matthew
Berman and many more!
Recently, we hosted an offline event in collaboration with Google at their
headquarters in Bangalore for our learners.

We are keen on sponsoring an ad on your youtube channel (and if you have a
newsletter then that as well)  and promoting our flagship course- the 2 day
AI mastermind, which consists of 16 hours of live training and learning AI
tools, LLM models, and live projects.

The 2-day AI Mastermind is rated 4.9/5 on Trustpilot and learners
consistently rave about the experience.

We would love to explore a potential partnership with you as we see a high
alignment with your work and our goals. Could you please share your
channel‚Äôs demographics according to Age group, Audience profile and
Geographical Location which will help us understand our alignment better.

Meanwhile you can also check out Outskill‚Äôs website
<https://outskill-com.jmailroute.net/x/d?c=49480922&l=312d6f46-ce72-493b-b42b-e952f728221f&r=8483ddc7-8664-4191-9458-b15f01aca62a>
to
know more about us.

Excited to kick off a partnership with you!

Best regards,
Sheel
Partnerships Manager, Outskill

subject: Re: CollaborationÔºöLocal AI Supercomputer, 80GB RAM, Zero Token Fees

triggerMessage.subject: CollaborationÔºöLocal AI Supercomputer, 80GB RAM, Zero Token Fees
triggerMessage.body:
Hi there,

I'm Simon, hope you're doing great!

We've been following your content on *YouTube *for a while, and we really
love your take on* AI hardware/tech gadgets*.

We are reaching out from the team behind *Tiiny AI Pocket Lab*. We have
created the *world's smallest personal AI supercomputer*, officially
certified by *Guinness World Records*.


*About Tiiny:*

Tiiny is a pocket-sized AI supercomputer designed for privacy-first
computing. It runs massive LLMs (up to 120B parameters) fully offline at
blazing speeds of up to 40 tokens/s. Powered by the PowerInfer engine
(8.5k+ GitHub stars), it is the ultimate cost-effective lab for developers.

Tiiny functions as a drop-in replacement for cloud APIs, offering full
OpenAI compatibility for seamless integration into your current projects.
Acting as your personal *Token Factory, *You can freely develop and
experiment with your projects without worrying about unpredictable token
fees.

If you need a quick refresher, you can watch the TiinyOS and Tiiny API
walkthrough videos anytime at these links:

   - TiinyOS: https://youtu.be/YvNVk8cuxw8
   <https://l.gotourl.es/l/1d6715e48bb48f30ef8d7abf2ba2b272c5d8a088?u=13508529>
   - Using Tiiny as a token factory: https://youtu.be/zEnsrz2W5L4
   <https://l.gotourl.es/l/cc487777242e14470bb6624ac6cb4021322821ff?u=13508529>


We would love to invite you to create a *dedicated review of *the Tiiny AI
Pocket Lab.
*Please be advised:*

   1. We are targeting a campaign release by *March*. To ensure we can lock
   in a slot in your schedule for this timeline, we are happy to proceed with
   a *paid sponsorship.*
   2. Could you please share your rates for a dedicated video?
   Alternatively, if you have other collaborative ideas, we are open to
   hearing them!


Looking forward to hearing from you!

Best regards,
Tiiny AI Team

conversationHistory.body:
Hello!



I'm an aspiring backend dev wanting to master Typescript. I have some backend TS experience, and some years working in Java at a large tech company.



I purchased the Pro Complete series when it was on sale in December, and I'm finally getting around to looking through it more closely. It feels quite a bit over my head currently, and I see one section on React that is not relevant to the work I'll be doing. I'm wondering, from your perspective, how relevant is the rest of the Pro Complete series to a backend-only TS dev (API design/implementation, database connection, etc)? I'm not planning to author any TS libraries, but will likely work for SaaS companies designing and implementing their backends. I'm wondering if the Essentials series will be sufficient for me.



Thanks,

conversationHistory.body:
Hi Haze,

Thank you so much for getting back to me and for extending the holiday discount‚ÄîI really appreciate the gesture.

I ran into a small technical issue when trying to use the link. It seems the checkout system doesn't allow me to combine the holiday code with the India Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) pricing. When I apply the code, it defaults to the global price, which brings the total to $198.

Given my current situation of being out of work for six months, $198 is still quite a high hurdle for me to clear right now.

Is there any way to generate a specific code that applies a further discount to the India regional price, or perhaps a different way to process this so I can get closer to a manageable amount?

Thank you again for your patience and for trying to help me make this work.

Best regards,

Siva

>>
>> While the India regional pricing is helpful, my current situation of being out of work for six months makes it a bit out of reach at the moment. Would you be open to providing a one-time additional discount code so I can repurchase the course and begin my TypeScript journey?

>>

>>

That sale discount didn't stack with the PPP discount sorry. The best price for you would be the regionally discounted license. If you pay for a full license you'll get the bonus interviews and access to your license anywhere.

Hi Matt,

I‚Äôm going to assume this is an automated email, but I‚Äôll still reply anyways.

I‚Äôm interested in both AI and Types to further improve my universal app starterkit.

I‚Äôm even quoting one of your tweets<https://x.com/mattpocockuk/status/1802225497499168774?s=46> in my blog and explainer video üòÑ

Basically, you‚Äôve helped inspire one of the starterkit‚Äôs main USP‚Äôs: Using Zod as the Single Source of Truth to derive other data structured from + keep everything in sync and typesafe. (With nice side-effects like automatic docgen to further help teams and AI tools avoid hallucinations)

I specifically liked your recent blogpost on better AGENTS.md and keeping that clean.

I‚Äôll likely end up applying those recommendations in the starter too.

Thanks again,

subject: Re: A quick question...

triggerMessage.subject: Re: A quick question...
triggerMessage.body:
Hi Matt,

Longtime reader of your work on Twitter/X, but largely new to your more
organized education materials. As a frontend/full-stack dev with ~9 years
of professional experience in JS/TS/React/Node/Vercel/etc, I am always
looking for great sources to help me get better.

Your work has really spoken to me on multiple levels

   1. Your work around following and growing in this fast-paced era of AI
   engineering - it's daunting to keep up with everything that is changing,
   and not just use the ever-changing tools of the day, but *use them well*.
   Looking for quality, tested, focused changes I can make to my day-to-day
   workflow makes keeping up feel manageable, even exciting
   2. Leveling up in my fundamentals - I was a bootcamp grad, I have no
   formal CS training, and in my career in startups I've found that the focus
   is almost always entirely on shipping and not on learning the fundamentals.
   I often feel like I just sort of skipped past a lot of that, and now as I
   look to become a contributor worthy of senior/staff level, missing those
   foundations really matters. Typescript is an area where I know some
   technical growth can pay major professional dividends.

I'm really excited to dive more deeply into your work, as it seems like you
structure things in a very intentional way to have others learn.

Best,
Andrew

Understanding constraints (extends)?

Using generics with functions vs. types?

Something else?

Great! If you're just starting out with TypeScript, I'd recommend beginning with the fundamentals:
**Start with the basics** - Learn how TypeScript differs from JavaScript, type annotations, interfaces, and basic types. Most learners find it helpful to work through exercises that show you how types prevent bugs.
**Practice incrementally** - Don't try to learn everything at once. Focus on types first, then move into more advanced concepts like generics, utility types, and advanced patterns once you're comfortable with the foundation.
Is there a specific area you're curious about, or would you like help navigating the Total TypeScript resources available?

Hey Joel,

I hear the frustration‚ÄîTypeScript can feel overwhelming at first, but you've got this. The good news is you already have access to Total TypeScript, which is designed to take you from confused to confident.

Here's what I'd suggest:
- Start with the fundamentals section if you haven't already‚Äîit's built to click things into place
- Don't try to learn everything at once. Pick one concept and really nail it before moving on
- TypeScript is actually going to *add* to your skillset, not replace it. The demand for TypeScript skills is growing, not shrinking

What specific part of TypeScript is throwing you off? Types? Generics? Syntax? Let me know and I can point you toward the exact lessons that'll help.

You've got the course‚Äîlet's make sure you get real value from it.

subject: Re: PAID COLLABORATION [NOTTA ECOSYSTEM]

triggerMessage.subject: PAID COLLABORATION [NOTTA ECOSYSTEM]
triggerMessage.body:
*Hello Matt,*

*Just want to keep this short and straightforward!*

*I'm Huzaifa, and I work at an influencer marketing agency, currently
focusing on the tech and lifestyle industries.*

*We're currently collaborating with one of our partner brands, Notta, an AI
productivity and transcription app, **and are looking to collaborate with
US-based creators whose audience includes students, tech and
AI professionals, founders, and remote workers. Your content stands out as
a strong match for this campaign.*


*If you're interested, could you please share your media kit and rates for
deliverables across social media, especially Youtube integrations and
dedicated videos and X? This will help us check whether a collaboration
would work out between us!*

*However, if you think this may not be a good fit for your audience, let us
know, and we'll remove you from our mailing list.*

*Looking forward to hearing from you!*
-- 
*Huzaifa*
*Awaisson Media*

conversationHistory.body:
*Hello Matt,*

*Just want to keep this short and straightforward!*

*I'm Huzaifa, and I work at an influencer marketing agency, currently
focusing on the tech and lifestyle industries.*

*We're currently collaborating with one of our partner brands, Notta, an AI
productivity and transcription app, **and are looking to collaborate with
US-based creators whose audience includes students, tech and
AI professionals, founders, and remote workers. Your content stands out as
a strong match for this campaign.*


*If you're interested, could you please share your media kit and rates for
deliverables across social media, especially Youtube integrations and
dedicated videos and X? This will help us check whether a collaboration
would work out between us!*

*However, if you think this may not be a good fit for your audience, let us
know, and we'll remove you from our mailing list.*

*Looking forward to hearing from you!*
-- 
*Huzaifa*
*Awaisson Media*

This is an automated reply to let you know that your email has been received and we will get back to you as quickly as possible. We work 9-5 Pacific Monday through Friday and take most "bank holidays" off. 


You can find community support in the Total TypeScript Discord channel: 


https://www.totaltypescript.com/discord


If you've got code questions/comments/opinions, Discord is the best channel!


--


If you've purchased Total TypeScript and are looking for an invoice or receipt, you can find that here:


https://www.totaltypescript.com/purchases


--


Invoices are customizable and you can enter company/tax information there. The generated PDFs are also fully editable so please feel free to adjust them to suit your specific needs.


The Total TypeScript FAQ has answers to many common questions:


https://www.totaltypescript.com/faq


--


Will you take 15 seconds share Total TypeScript? It really helps us get the word out. üôè


üëâ Send a tweet about Total TypeScript!

subject: Re: üëã  Feedback from bradwebber@gmail.com about Total TypeScript

triggerMessage.subject: üëã  Feedback from bradwebber@gmail.com about Total TypeScript
triggerMessage.body:
Hey Matt, I hope you‚Äôre well. I just watched your video titled ‚ÄúShip working
code while you sleep with the Ralph Wiggum technique‚Äù on YouTube. Thank you for
putting that together; it is fantastic. QQ: When you specify the number of
iterations, does that apply to a single item in your PRD or all items? In other
words, if your loop picks up a task and fails to implement that task, does the
next iteration in the loop pick up the failed task and try again, or does it
potentially pick another task? Perhaps another way to ask is: if you specify a
max-iterations of 10 but your PRD has 20 items, will your ralph loop stop after
implementing 10 items (assuming it implements each item successfully on its
first attempt)?

subject: Re: Paid collaboration with DevTools ‚Äî Modern API Testing Tool

triggerMessage.subject: Paid collaboration with DevTools ‚Äî Modern API Testing Tool
triggerMessage.body:
Hey Matt,

I really appreciate your content around developer workflows and tooling. We
think DevTools aligns well with those themes.

I‚Äôm reaching out from DevTools ‚Äî we built a Go-based API client that lets
you turn real browser traffic (HAR files) into replayable API flows. It‚Äôs
way faster than Postman and Bruno, and you can export everything as
readable YAML for version control and Git review.

DevTools is open source, works as both a CLI and a desktop app, and has a
visual builder for flow trees and reusable checks. It‚Äôs perfect for
developers and QA teams looking to speed up API testing and automate flows
in CI.

We‚Äôre running a paid promo for creators ‚Äî happy to discuss rates for a
sponsored feature or demo.

If you‚Äôre interested, let me know and I‚Äôll send over more details!

Thanks,
Mustafa

Hey Matt,

I manage influencer sponsorships for Willow.

We want to work with you on a paid sponsored video and think your audience would genuinely love what we've built.


Willow is a voice typing tool that lets you write anywhere on your computer with your voice. Imagine Apple's built-in dictation tool if it were 3x more accurate, fast, and intelligent.¬†


Users love using voice to draft emails, write reports, and prompt AI tools like Cursor or Claude. We're used by over 50k+ professionals and featured in Business Insider, TechCrunch, and more.

Would you be open to doing a dedicated tutorial or review?


Best,
Allan

triggerMessage.subject: Paid Collaboration Opportunity with Pippit (AI Website Tool)
triggerMessage.body:
Hi,

I hope this message finds you well.

My name is CJ from SEI Marketing, and we are reaching out on behalf of
Pippit, an AI-powered website tool focused on improving efficiency and
productivity for digital users.

We are currently engaging select creators for an upcoming global campaign
and identified your content as highly aligned with Pippit‚Äôs positioning.
Your work in AI and productivity-focused content stands out as a strong
potential fit for this collaboration.

Proposed Deliverables:
One (1) video published on YouTube, Instagram, or TikTok (with preference
for YouTube and Instagram)
On-camera, real-person presentation with the creator‚Äôs face visible
A clear and authentic explanation or demonstration of Pippit

Usage Rights (Instagram & TikTok only):
30-day ad authorization code
Copyright authorization for paid media usage

If this opportunity is of interest, may we kindly ask for your current rate
or rate card for this type of collaboration? This will help us ensure
alignment before sharing the full campaign brief, timeline, and
collaboration details.

Thank you for your time and consideration. We look forward to the
possibility of working together.

Kind regards,
CJ
SEI Marketing

subject: Re: A quick question...

triggerMessage.subject: Re: A quick question...
triggerMessage.body:
Hi Matt,

I know this is an automated message, but I wanted to reach out anyway. I‚Äôve
been a product manager for over 20 years and a self-described "geek" long
before that. While I‚Äôve dabbled in PHP, HTML, and CSS for WordPress sites,
I‚Äôve never been a coder who builds from scratch‚Äîthe barrier to entry for
creating production-ready software was always too high for someone with my
schedule and family commitments.

However, "vibe coding" with AI has changed everything. I started with
Lovable and have since moved on to using OpenCode (best) and Cursor
(Antigravity is too flaky). I‚Äôve been able to build extremely useful tools
and websites for my small family business, and with the integration of
GitHub and Vercel, the deployment process essentially takes care of itself.

I‚Äôm interested in staying current with these self-work tools, but I'm also
fascinated by what this means for the profession of software development.
As a product leader, my job spans business & vision vision, through
ideation, and to prod. We are seeing the removal of the primary bottleneck:
the cost and time associated with manual software production and
maintenance. For example, I recently used Codex 5.2 to add a complex 3D
modeling feature to an internal app for my wife‚Äôs business. I simply spoke
the requirements, and it handled the documentation, UI integration, and
database updates instantly.

In my career, that kind of update would have taken weeks or months of PRDs,
release planning, and architectural compromises. I have also seen cycle
times of years. Now, I can move from an idea to a preview environment in
minutes. The speed of iteration‚Äîwhich Agile and SAFe could never solve‚Äîis
finally here because we are no longer limited by manual syntax entry by
devs.

I followed you after seeing a recommendation from Theo at T3, specifically
regarding your agents.md article. The idea that "best practices" are now
prompts (or just conversations) rather than rigid frameworks is a massive
shift. Even if the AI doesn't get it right the first time, the cost of
iterating five different versions is lower than the cost of a single
planning meeting.

Software development is having its "horse to engine" moment. And what this
means beyond just software development as well.
Best regards,

Graeme Port

conversationHistory.body:
Hi Matt,

I know this is an automated message, but I wanted to reach out anyway. I‚Äôve
been a product manager for over 20 years and a self-described "geek" long
before that. While I‚Äôve dabbled in PHP, HTML, and CSS for WordPress sites,
I‚Äôve never been a coder who builds from scratch‚Äîthe barrier to entry for
creating production-ready software was always too high for someone with my
schedule and family commitments.

However, "vibe coding" with AI has changed everything. I started with
Lovable and have since moved on to using OpenCode (best) and Cursor
(Antigravity is too flaky). I‚Äôve been able to build extremely useful tools
and websites for my small family business, and with the integration of
GitHub and Vercel, the deployment process essentially takes care of itself.

I‚Äôm interested in staying current with these self-work tools, but I'm also
fascinated by what this means for the profession of software development.
As a product leader, my job spans business & vision vision, through
ideation, and to prod. We are seeing the removal of the primary bottleneck:
the cost and time associated with manual software production and
maintenance. For example, I recently used Codex 5.2 to add a complex 3D
modeling feature to an internal app for my wife‚Äôs business. I simply spoke
the requirements, and it handled the documentation, UI integration, and
database updates instantly.

In my career, that kind of update would have taken weeks or months of PRDs,
release planning, and architectural compromises. I have also seen cycle
times of years. Now, I can move from an idea to a preview environment in
minutes. The speed of iteration‚Äîwhich Agile and SAFe could never solve‚Äîis
finally here because we are no longer limited by manual syntax entry by
devs.

I followed you after seeing a recommendation from Theo at T3, specifically
regarding your agents.md article. The idea that "best practices" are now
prompts (or just conversations) rather than rigid frameworks is a massive
shift. Even if the AI doesn't get it right the first time, the cost of
iterating five different versions is lower than the cost of a single
planning meeting.

Software development is having its "horse to engine" moment. And what this
means beyond just software development as well.
Best regards,

Graeme Port

subject: Re: A quick question...

triggerMessage.subject: Re: A quick question...
triggerMessage.body:
Hey Matt,



Yeah, your TypeScript content has been genuinely useful over the years‚Äîthose short videos on generics finally made things click.



I‚Äôve been watching your AI Hero pivot with interest. Similar trajectory here‚ÄîI recently created an ‚ÄúAI Context Engineer‚Äù role for myself at Aflac after realising AI was changing how I work.



What interests me most:

Context engineering‚Äîthe gap between AI that occasionally helps and AI that consistently delivers. I‚Äôve been building systems that accumulate knowledge across development sessions.



Multi-agent coordination‚Äîorchestrating specialised agents for different development phases. The coordination problem is where it gets interesting.

Evaluation‚Äîhow do you actually measure if your AI setup is improving? Currently building harnesses to test different context configurations.



What I want to learn more about: how to drive adoption. Part of my role is educating engineers in my organisation and building confidence with AI tools. You‚Äôve done this at scale with TypeScript‚Äîcurious what‚Äôs worked for you in getting developers past the initial scepticism.



Barry



Sent from my iPhone

I want to learn how to effectively use AI to boost my productivity and get
more stuff done. I don‚Äôt like it when AI does everything by itself but

there yet.

established. Bleeding edge tech is interesting but of no real use if it‚Äòs
going to be replaced in a year.

Tim

triggerMessage.body:
‚ÄãHi Matt,

‚ÄãGreat to hear from you. I‚Äôve been following your work in the TypeScript
ecosystem for a while.

‚ÄãComing from a structured world like TypeScript, AI feels like a massive
paradigm shift. I‚Äôm most interested in *integration and application layers*.
I want to move beyond just using ChatGPT in the browser and start building
AI features directly into my applications.

‚ÄãSpecifically, I want to learn:

   - ‚ÄãHow to reliably integrate LLMs into TypeScript codebases (using tools
   like the Vercel AI SDK or LangChain).
   - ‚ÄãHow to constrain AI outputs so they are type-safe and predictable.
   - ‚ÄãThe best patterns for building RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation)
   systems.

‚ÄãLooking forward to seeing what you‚Äôre working on!



Regards,
Mandar

subject: Accepted: Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph @ Wed Feb 11, 2026 9am - 1pm (PST) (team@aihero.dev)

triggerMessage.subject: Accepted: Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph @ Wed Feb 11, 2026 9am - 1pm (PST) (team@aihero.dev)
triggerMessage.body:
Bart≈Çomiej Wojcieszek has accepted this invitation.

Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph
Wednesday Feb 11, 2026 ‚ãÖ 9am ‚Äì 1pm
Pacific Time - Los Angeles



Half-day live workshop ‚Ä¢ February 11, 9 AM PST ‚Ä¢ Limited to 40 developers ‚Ä¢ üéâ **{percentOff}% off** ‚Äî Sale ends ! Only  left.The Ralph  technique runs AI agents in loops with structured PRDs and feedback mechanisms. It's real, it's working in production, and you'll build it today.Geoffrey Huntley figured out the pattern. Matt Pocock validated it with people shipping code. The technique has a name‚ÄîRalph (yeah, like Ralph Wiggum from The Simpsons, because of course it does)‚Äîand developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasks‚Äîreal tasks, not toy examples‚Äîand create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Reserve Your SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Claude Code, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundation‚Äîonce it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lie‚Äîyou'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessing‚Äîit's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just execute‚Äîit validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Hooking Up Ralph To Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manually‚Äîit's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually execute‚Äînot theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

Organizer
team@aihero.dev
team@aihero.dev

Guests
(Guest list has been hidden at organizer's request)

subject: Past materials

triggerMessage.subject: Past materials
triggerMessage.body:
Hi Matt, big fan of your TS work. Been trying to get into AI and was happy
and bummed out to find your AI Hero site some weeks ago. Happy because you
are a great instructor but bummed because I missed the second cohort by a
few days (I'm assuming there was a first one which I therefore missed) and
now the event about Ralph sold out in just a few hours... Man I'm so sad...
I don't want to miss out on the opportunity to learn all you have to
teach... Please, tell me, are you planning to repeat the cohorts/events in
the future? Again, big fan of your work, thanks.

subject: Re: A quick question...

triggerMessage.subject: Re: A quick question...
triggerMessage.body:
Hi Matt. I am very aware of who you are - I've paid for your courses (I
think the mailing list should give it away lol), and follow you on LinkedIn
and YouTube.

I am a front-end swe at Google. Formerly at Dialogflow and Firebase, now at
Google News. I currently contribute to the Gemini Web UI.

I want to learn how others are using AI and how I can improve or tweak my
ever evolving daily workflows. I am very skeptical of this Ralph concept

On Thu, Jan 22, 2026 at 7:17‚ÄØPM Matt Pocock (AI Hero) <matt@aihero.dev>
wrote:

> Hey Erez,
>
> The future of AI coding is a loop. It‚Äôs one of the simplest primitives
> available to developers, but we‚Äôve been criminally underusing it in the AI
> coding world.
>
> Instead, we‚Äôre stuck in that frustrating cycle with AI coding assistants.
> You ask for Feature A, get half a solution, manually fix it, ask for
> Feature B, and it breaks Feature A. Rinse, repeat.
>
> But here‚Äôs what‚Äôs actually happening right now in production: developers
> are setting up agents that run in loops with structured feedback
> mechanisms. They point them at GitHub backlogs. Real PRs get created.
> Without constant babysitting.
>
> It‚Äôs called the Ralph Wiggum technique, and it‚Äôs not magic. It‚Äôs a simple,
> learnable pattern.
>
> *I‚Äôm running **a live workshop on February 11 at 9 AM PST*
> <https://7751c435.click.convertkit-mail2.com/92uxvv0wgxfnh64wv7kh9hzoxm933bwh22llp/dphehmued0v29ncm/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuYWloZXJvLmRldi9zL3JhbHBoLXdvcmtzaG9wLTAx>
> to teach you exactly how to build it. We‚Äôre capping at 40 developers
> because this is hands-on. You‚Äôll be debugging YOUR code, not just watching
> me code.
>
> Here‚Äôs what you‚Äôll leave with:
>
>    - Your own bash loop running
>    - Feedback mechanisms that let agents catch their own mistakes
>    - Your GitHub backlog wired up to actually execute tasks
>    - The PRD structure that makes agents do what you actually want
>
> By 1 PM, you‚Äôll have real PRs being generated from your actual issues.
>
> *Sign-ups are open now.* Limited spots, and we‚Äôve got a discount running
> through Feb 5th. Grab yours before they sell out.
>
> The full details are here, including what actually breaks, why this works
> now (and didn‚Äôt before), and exactly what you need to bring.
> *Secure Your Seat*
> <https://7751c435.click.convertkit-mail2.com/92uxvv0wgxfnh64wv7kh9hzoxm933bwh22llp/dphehmued0v29ncm/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuYWloZXJvLmRldi9zL3JhbHBoLXdvcmtzaG9wLTAx>
>
> See you on February 11.

¬≠ ¬≠ ¬≠ ¬≠ ¬≠ ¬≠ ¬≠ ¬≠ ¬≠ ¬≠ ¬†

Fly.io Newsletter

Hi there,

It's been a minute, but that's because we've been busy working on something pretty fun: Sprites ( https://sprites.dev/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )! They're stateful sandbox environments that you can easily checkpoint and restore. Thomas says they're "ball-point disposable computers," ( https://fly.io/blog/design-and-implementation/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) but whatever you call them, they're probably worth checking out if you're sick of trying to build or test anything in ephemeral sandboxes.

You only pay for the resources you actually consume while running them, but you can kick the tires now with $30 of free credit. Let us know what you build!

Product updates

The Fresh Produce ( https://community.fly.io/c/fresh-produce/27?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) section of our Community Forum is where we update y'all on what's new. There's a lot over there about Sprites, but there's some other important stuff going on, too:

* Postgres 17 is here ( https://community.fly.io/t/you-asked-and-we-shipped-postgres-17-on-mpg/26430?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )! (For people who like shiny new indexes, planner improvements, and general "Postgres got faster again" vibes.)
* The experience of launching an app from the dashboard got a makeover! ( https://community.fly.io/t/launch-your-app-from-the-dashboard-better-ui-heck-yeah/26838?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )

Inside Flyball

We're excited be able to share Sprites with you, and we're honestly having fun using them ourselves. We ran a lil "show and tell" at our last Town Hall meeting; here are a couple of things that the folks working at Fly.io are building:

* A progressive web app chat UI ( https://github.com/clouvet/sprite-mobile?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) for accessing Claude Code running in YOLO mode on a Sprite, an ideal vibe-coding interface on your phone. It allows input by text, voice, and image, persists sessions across clients, and seamlessly networks with your other Sprites through Tailscale.
* spritessh ( https://github.com/jbellerb/spritessh?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) is a simple bridge so your legacy (anything older than 1 week) tools can use Sprites over plain SSH.
* A project ( https://github.com/symkat/Fly-Workspaces?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) that provisions code-server to your Sprite so that you can do development work from anywhere you have a web browser, even an iPad!
* Bookworm ( https://bookworm-demo-v53c.sprites.app/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ): A 100% vibe-coded web app, running on a Sprite, for tracking your book reading list. You can search for books and add them to your list (powered by the Open Library API) or add them manually, then mark them as started/finished reading.

Feature story

We'd normally do a whole thing here, diving into the background of what Sprites are and how they were designed, but Kurt and Thomas wrote quite a few words on those topics already, so we'll send you straight to the source:

* What are Sprites, exactly? ( https://fly.io/blog/code-and-let-live/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )
* The Design & Implementation of Sprites ( https://fly.io/blog/design-and-implementation/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )

Thoughts/comments/cool stuff you've spun up on Sprites since you started reading this two minutes ago? You know where to find us. (On the other side of this newsletter! Just hit "reply.")

Thanks,

The Fly.io Team

Fly.io Newsletter

Hi there,

It's been a minute, but that's because we've been busy working on something pretty fun: Sprites ( https://sprites.dev/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )! They're stateful sandbox environments that you can easily checkpoint and restore. Thomas says they're "ball-point disposable computers," ( https://fly.io/blog/design-and-implementation/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) but whatever you call them, they're probably worth checking out if you're sick of trying to build or test anything in ephemeral sandboxes.

You only pay for the resources you actually consume while running them, but you can kick the tires now with $30 of free credit. Let us know what you build!

Product updates

The Fresh Produce ( https://community.fly.io/c/fresh-produce/27?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) section of our Community Forum is where we update y'all on what's new. There's a lot over there about Sprites, but there's some other important stuff going on, too:

* Postgres 17 is here ( https://community.fly.io/t/you-asked-and-we-shipped-postgres-17-on-mpg/26430?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )! (For people who like shiny new indexes, planner improvements, and general "Postgres got faster again" vibes.)
* The experience of launching an app from the dashboard got a makeover! ( https://community.fly.io/t/launch-your-app-from-the-dashboard-better-ui-heck-yeah/26838?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )

Inside Flyball

We're excited be able to share Sprites with you, and we're honestly having fun using them ourselves. We ran a lil "show and tell" at our last Town Hall meeting; here are a couple of things that the folks working at Fly.io are building:

* A progressive web app chat UI ( https://github.com/clouvet/sprite-mobile?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) for accessing Claude Code running in YOLO mode on a Sprite, an ideal vibe-coding interface on your phone. It allows input by text, voice, and image, persists sessions across clients, and seamlessly networks with your other Sprites through Tailscale.
* spritessh ( https://github.com/jbellerb/spritessh?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) is a simple bridge so your legacy (anything older than 1 week) tools can use Sprites over plain SSH.
* A project ( https://github.com/symkat/Fly-Workspaces?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) that provisions code-server to your Sprite so that you can do development work from anywhere you have a web browser, even an iPad!
* Bookworm ( https://bookworm-demo-v53c.sprites.app/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ): A 100% vibe-coded web app, running on a Sprite, for tracking your book reading list. You can search for books and add them to your list (powered by the Open Library API) or add them manually, then mark them as started/finished reading.

Feature story

We'd normally do a whole thing here, diving into the background of what Sprites are and how they were designed, but Kurt and Thomas wrote quite a few words on those topics already, so we'll send you straight to the source:

* What are Sprites, exactly? ( https://fly.io/blog/code-and-let-live/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )
* The Design & Implementation of Sprites ( https://fly.io/blog/design-and-implementation/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )

Thoughts/comments/cool stuff you've spun up on Sprites since you started reading this two minutes ago? You know where to find us. (On the other side of this newsletter! Just hit "reply.")

Thanks,

The Fly.io Team

subject: Re: [aih] Re: Plan for 2026

triggerMessage.subject: Re: [aih] Re: Plan for 2026
triggerMessage.body:
Okay got it!

First, great news about the workshop sales selling out üôå that is great
signal.

Given this, and of course your own motivation being a huge piece of the
success, here's what we're thinking for the big picture year long plan at a
very high level:

*Each quarter is punctuated by a cohort and we work backwards from that. *

Within each quarter, you'll have a combination of components:

   - *A smaller product launch. *Think something on par with the half day
   workshop or AI-SDK Crash Course)that provides both revenue AND
   assets/insights that carry forward and compound
   - *At least one new FREEBIE launch, aimed at the top of funnel. *This
   would tie into your Twitter/Youtube activity and be designed to get people
   from those platforms to the list
   - *At least one cohort. *I say at least one, because this could *also* turn
   into a rhythm where on month 1 of a quarter you re-run a past cohort, and
   month 3 you launch a new one. This exact rhythm could vary, but the goal
   would be to blend the leverage of cohorts that people missed the first time
   AND introducing new things that you're excited about.

In the case of Q1 (now), since it's almost the end of Jan already and this
cohort is effectively your small product launch in Feb, I don't think we
will be able to fit a re-run in but we can absolutely plan for it at the
top of Q2.

We'd map this out on a calendar to make sure it's clear and the overlapping
timelines make sense, but wanted to share this first for an initial gut
check.

How's that land for you?








-Alex

üìô  my book: tiny.mba
ü§ù  my community: indyhall.org
üìà  my 10 year goal: 10k.city

conversationHistory.body:
Just a quick progress update: me and Joel had a chat about plans for this
year and I'm thinking a simple plan works best:

Plan is to do *four cohorts of new material this year*, dates to be
finalized tomorrow.

First will be Ralph-based, sometime in March, likely around 10 weeks away.

Others I think it makes sense for now to play them by ear and set deadlines
for when we want to solidify the content.

That should let us plan backwards effectively from those dates, with the
knowledge that we may alter them if we want to change course (do a smaller
ship between two cohorts, or drop a cohort for 2 small ships, or repeat a
cohort and do a smaller ship in the downtime). No plan survives contact
with the anemone, after all.

Matt

Proposal would be:

Ralph Cohort: 30th March
Cohort 2: 29th June
Cohort 3: 14th September
Cohort 4: 7th December

On Mon, Jan 19, 2026 at 5:58‚ÄØPM Matt Pocock <mattpocockvoice@gmail.com>
wrote:

> Just a quick progress update: me and Joel had a chat about plans for this
> year and I'm thinking a simple plan works best:
>
> Plan is to do *four cohorts of new material this year*, dates to be
> finalized tomorrow.
>
> First will be Ralph-based, sometime in March, likely around 10 weeks away.
>
> Others I think it makes sense for now to play them by ear and set
> deadlines for when we want to solidify the content.
>
> That should let us plan backwards effectively from those dates, with the
> knowledge that we may alter them if we want to change course (do a smaller
> ship between two cohorts, or drop a cohort for 2 small ships, or repeat a
> cohort and do a smaller ship in the downtime). No plan survives contact
> with the anemone, after all.
>
> Matt
>

Amy and I talked about this yesterday and think it's a great set of dates
to scaffold backwards from! Also love an 8 week lead time to the next
cohort üòç

That said - are you open to guidance on this next cohort being Ralph vs a
second run of the assistant cohort?

Remember from our call that our recommendation for this year is to think
about launches/events as layered events, strategically staggering new
releases between relaunches with improvements and additions, as well as
smaller experimental releases (workshops, crash courses, etc)

A few reasons we both agree that this would be a more advantageous path:

- our recommended rhytm for the year is going to be a mix of new launches +
relaunches. This not only helps you increase the income for effort on each
course, it also helps demonstrate and reinforce your investment in each
ideas you teach to the audience.

- the half day workshop in early Feb about Ralph will let you learn a lot
about the response to that topic and how/what to expand for the larger
cohort version of on the same topic, BUT if anything changes we'll likely
end up having to change the plan and have less time to work on the March
cohort.

However if you run the Assistant cohort again in March, that lets you:

- increase the leverage of that material, in addition to any fixes to the
material itself, with a lot less effort than a new cohort now

- let us get a running start on the relaunch of that cohort while you're
running the half day workshop, without worry about the workshop changing
the course of that work in a significant way

- let YOU pace your effort and time between the half day workshop and the
next cohort better as well

- assuming the Ralph feedback and demand DOES match your expectations, a
best case scenario is you decide to fast track the 2nd cohort of 2026 and
it's possible because the first one isn't being produced from scratch and
you could actually do both in parallel.

Overall, this second version helps you retain a lot more flexibility and
optionality that fits the fast changing landscape, while also keeping a
pace and rhythm that holds people's attention.

Hopefully it's clear why it's pretty important that we get on the same page
about this now üòÑ

I'm sure there are some tweaks we can make, and most importantly this
doesn't change anything about your current plans to do the smaller Ralph
workshop!

How's this land for you? Questions or concerns or strong disagreement we
should talk thru?

We wanna get working on the plan for the year and this is gonna be a
foundation, so we wanna get it right!

Happy to do a quick call to chat this thru too if it's helpful.

> To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an
> email to bricks+unsubscribe@aihero.dev.
>

Thanks for the above. But I do disagree: I'm pretty convinced that Ralph
for Cohort 1 is the way forward.

As a bit of signal, we opened up a Ralph workshop sales page at $375 and it
sold out (40 seats) in 3 hours.

I think this bit of signal, plus my own passionate interest, is leading me
in the direction of "let's do Ralph as cohort 1". I do my best work when
I'm interested in the topic, and feel a strong surge of consumer interest.
The half-day workshop work directly feeds into the cohort, so I don't feel
like it's too much of a push for me to get a whole cohort ready on this
topic before mid-March.

>> Cohort 3: 14th September
>> Cohort 4: 7th December
>>
>> On Mon, Jan 19, 2026 at 5:58‚ÄØPM Matt Pocock <mattpocockvoice@gmail.com>
>> wrote:
>>
>>> Just a quick progress update: me and Joel had a chat about plans for
>>> this year and I'm thinking a simple plan works best:
>>>
>>> Plan is to do *four cohorts of new material this year*, dates to be
>>> finalized tomorrow.
>>>
>>> First will be Ralph-based, sometime in March, likely around 10 weeks
>>> away.
>>>
>>> Others I think it makes sense for now to play them by ear and set
>>> deadlines for when we want to solidify the content.
>>>
>>> That should let us plan backwards effectively from those dates, with the
>>> knowledge that we may alter them if we want to change course (do a smaller
>>> ship between two cohorts, or drop a cohort for 2 small ships, or repeat a
>>> cohort and do a smaller ship in the downtime). No plan survives contact
>>> with the anemone, after all.
>>>
>>> Matt
>>>
>> To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an
>> email to bricks+unsubscribe@aihero.dev.
>>
> To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an
> email to bricks+unsubscribe@aihero.dev.
>

Okay got it!

First, great news about the workshop sales selling out üôå that is great
signal.

Given this, and of course your own motivation being a huge piece of the
success, here's what we're thinking for the big picture year long plan at a
very high level:

*Each quarter is punctuated by a cohort and we work backwards from that. *

Within each quarter, you'll have a combination of components:

   - *A smaller product launch. *Think something on par with the half day
   workshop or AI-SDK Crash Course)that provides both revenue AND
   assets/insights that carry forward and compound
   - *At least one new FREEBIE launch, aimed at the top of funnel. *This
   would tie into your Twitter/Youtube activity and be designed to get people
   from those platforms to the list
   - *At least one cohort. *I say at least one, because this could *also* turn
   into a rhythm where on month 1 of a quarter you re-run a past cohort, and
   month 3 you launch a new one. This exact rhythm could vary, but the goal
   would be to blend the leverage of cohorts that people missed the first time
   AND introducing new things that you're excited about.

In the case of Q1 (now), since it's almost the end of Jan already and this
cohort is effectively your small product launch in Feb, I don't think we
will be able to fit a re-run in but we can absolutely plan for it at the
top of Q2.

We'd map this out on a calendar to make sure it's clear and the overlapping
timelines make sense, but wanted to share this first for an initial gut
check.

How's that land for you?








-Alex

üìô  my book: tiny.mba
ü§ù  my community: indyhall.org
üìà  my 10 year goal: 10k.city

wrote:

> Thanks for the above. But I do disagree: I'm pretty convinced that Ralph
> for Cohort 1 is the way forward.
>
> As a bit of signal, we opened up a Ralph workshop sales page at $375 and
> it sold out (40 seats) in 3 hours.
>
> I think this bit of signal, plus my own passionate interest, is leading me
> in the direction of "let's do Ralph as cohort 1". I do my best work when
> I'm interested in the topic, and feel a strong surge of consumer interest.
> The half-day workshop work directly feeds into the cohort, so I don't feel
> like it's too much of a push for me to get a whole cohort ready on this
> topic before mid-March.
>
> On Thu, Jan 22, 2026 at 2:20‚ÄØPM Alex Hillman <alex@indyhall.org> wrote:
>
>> Amy and I talked about this yesterday and think it's a great set of dates
>> to scaffold backwards from! Also love an 8 week lead time to the next
>> cohort üòç
>>
>> That said - are you open to guidance on this next cohort being Ralph vs a
>> second run of the assistant cohort?
>>
>> Remember from our call that our recommendation for this year is to think
>> about launches/events as layered events, strategically staggering new
>> releases between relaunches with improvements and additions, as well as
>> smaller experimental releases (workshops, crash courses, etc)
>>
>> A few reasons we both agree that this would be a more advantageous path:
>>
>> - our recommended rhytm for the year is going to be a mix of new launches
>> + relaunches. This not only helps you increase the income for effort on
>> each course, it also helps demonstrate and reinforce your investment in
>> each ideas you teach to the audience.
>>
>> - the half day workshop in early Feb about Ralph will let you learn a lot
>> about the response to that topic and how/what to expand for the larger
>> cohort version of on the same topic, BUT if anything changes we'll likely
>> end up having to change the plan and have less time to work on the March
>> cohort.
>>
>> However if you run the Assistant cohort again in March, that lets you:
>>
>> - increase the leverage of that material, in addition to any fixes to the
>> material itself, with a lot less effort than a new cohort now
>>
>> - let us get a running start on the relaunch of that cohort while you're
>> running the half day workshop, without worry about the workshop changing
>> the course of that work in a significant way
>>
>> - let YOU pace your effort and time between the half day workshop and the
>> next cohort better as well
>>
>> - assuming the Ralph feedback and demand DOES match your expectations, a
>> best case scenario is you decide to fast track the 2nd cohort of 2026 and
>> it's possible because the first one isn't being produced from scratch and
>> you could actually do both in parallel.
>>
>> Overall, this second version helps you retain a lot more flexibility and
>> optionality that fits the fast changing landscape, while also keeping a
>> pace and rhythm that holds people's attention.
>>
>> Hopefully it's clear why it's pretty important that we get on the same
>> page about this now üòÑ
>>
>> I'm sure there are some tweaks we can make, and most importantly this
>> doesn't change anything about your current plans to do the smaller Ralph
>> workshop!
>>
>> How's this land for you? Questions or concerns or strong disagreement we
>> should talk thru?
>>
>> We wanna get working on the plan for the year and this is gonna be a
>> foundation, so we wanna get it right!
>>
>> Happy to do a quick call to chat this thru too if it's helpful.
>>
>>
>>
