Hello matt@aihero.dev,

We're writing to let you know that the group you tried to contact (alumni) may not exist, or you may not have permission to post messages to the group. A few more details on why you weren't able to post:

 * You might have spelled or formatted the group name incorrectly.
 * The owner of the group may have removed this group.
 * You may need to join the group before receiving permission to post.
 * This group may not be open to posting.

If you have questions related to this or any other Google Group, visit the Help Center at https://support.google.com/a/vyg.co.nz/bin/topic.py?topic=25838.

Thanks,

vyg.co.nz admins

triggerMessage.subject: Re: Welcome to AI Hero!
triggerMessage.body:
Hi Matt's AI email reader/summary tool,

I binged the course in 2 days, loved it. I didn't fully code and run every
example but it was nice to be able to dive in if I wanted to. The only part
I wish there was some more instruction was on the setup. Like how the
frontend communicates with the backend. If I was going to try to implement
some of these features in my project I'd like a clear understanding of the
typical setup. Specifically, it took some digging to find that `useChat`
defaults to calling `/api/chat`. I had assumed you had done some routing in
the setup of the project so my first investigation was misguided.

It's a nitpick at best, I love the course/content and all the thumbs up I
got along the way üëç

Thank you,
Dan

Thank you for your time.

conversationHistory.body:
Hi Matt,
Hope all is well with you. I was just wondering if you offer any discounts
for your AI SDK Course. I noticed the launch price is gone, so I thought
maybe you could offer me a discount to grab it.

Regards,
Aminata

Hi Aminata,
Thanks for reaching out. I don't have the ability to authorize discounts on pricing, but I'd recommend reaching out directly through the product website or checking if there are any current promotions running. Depending on timing, there may be opportunities available.
Feel free to follow up if you have other questions.
Regards

>>>>> On January 14, 2026 at 5:47 PM GMT+1 alex@indyhall.org <mailto:alex@indyhall.org> wrote:
>>>>> 
>>>>> Okay so we're gonna be honest here that there's a very mixed message: 
>>>>> 
>>>>> 1 - On one hand, this is "useful for a lot of people" and the reason to react to it NOW is because of the buzz/attention it's getting and more specifically, that YOU are getting around it. 
>>>>> 
>>>>> 2 - On the other hand, you'd rather a small group and not looking to make a lot of money, happy with 6 people. 
>>>>> 
>>>>> So...which is it? :)
>>>>> 
>>>>> I'm wondering if the Ralph thing is less "good for the business" and more "fun experimental stuff I want to do and maybe has a bigger impact." 
>>>>> 
>>>>> If so, that's fine, let's treat it as such. Maybe having a 4th pillar (in addition to the 3 we mentioned yesterday) of "fun, fully Matt-driven free play experiments that don't need much from the team but recharge his batteries and MAYBE give us advantages for other things."
>>>>> 
>>>>> However if the question is "what's best for the business and by proxy, Matt, your audience, and the team?" then I we need to resolve this contradiction as quickly as possible!
>>>>> 
>>>>> No matter what I think it'd be wise for build in some "free play" - question is if Ralph is that or not? 
>>>>> 
>>>>> On Wed, Jan 14, 2026 at 7:55‚ÄØAM Matt Pocock <mattpocockvoice@gmail.com <mailto:mattpocockvoice@gmail.com>> wrote:
>>>>>> I totally defer to Joel on this. I'm no expert on pricing.
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> I would say that I would actually prefer a smaller group. I don't necessarily want it to devolve into a long workshop because that's more tedious to facilitate and also takes us further away from what the actual workshop will be.
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Not looking to make money out of this workshop. I'd be perfectly happy with six people. Though obviously I can probably facilitate up to 40.
>>>>>>  
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 5:34‚ÄØPM Amy Hoy <team@stackingthebricks.com <mailto:team@stackingthebricks.com>> wrote:
>>>>>>> Hey Matt!
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> The workshop plan sounds good to me. 
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> A couple things:
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> We sent our proposal to Joel and we suggest $199-249 for this half-day workshop, but based on your goals you've stated above, we think we should revise that to $99-129. Please don't take this the wrong way, we're not saying it doesn't have the value! 
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> Think of it as a "doorbuster." Something to lure people in with a no brainer price.
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> This will help you bring in a wider audience, appeal to many more people than just the ones already super hype about Ralph. Instead of preaching to the crowd, as it were. Somebody who just heard about it will likely open their wallet for $99. Fewer will do it for $199. Very few will do it for $399. 
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> Since your workshop can support more people, since it won't be very interactive ‚Äî more of a talk, really ‚Äî you don't need to limit seats, and could use this to potentially get lots of people into the habit of buying from you. 
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> Once somebody's bought from you once, they're very likely to buy from you again!
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> The other elements to the price are "comparison to your other offerings' price" and "how easy is Ralph to sell?" 
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> If you price it at $400, that's almost as much as somebody would pay for your week-long cohort, with discounts.
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> And Ralph is not a big, sweeping thing, general thing, compared to what you teach in those cohorts. Right now, it's very niche. And in our experience so far, selling niche "branches" off the AI tree is not working as well as more general whole project approaches. Makes sense, because the field is still new.
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> This doesn't close the door on offering a higher-tier Ralph offering later. 
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> You don't have to add this to your library, even. It could be a one-off special event.
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> So, especially considering this is a quick launch you want to use to draw in the audience from your appearances, $99-129 is a price that makes an easy sell to the widest audience and will leave people feeling like they got a great value.
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> Lastly, let's not call it a cohort, which makes it sound like a multi-day course. It's a 1-day workshop. :) 
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> Amy
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> ‚Äî
>>>>>>> Amy Hoy
>>>>>>> stackingthebricks.com <http://stackingthebricks.com/>
>>>>>>>> On January 13, 2026 at 6:58 AM MST mattpocockvoice@gmail.com <mailto:mattpocockvoice@gmail.com> wrote:
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Defer to Joel, but probably $400-500?
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 1:08‚ÄØPM Alex Hillman <alex@indyhall.org <mailto:alex@indyhall.org>> wrote:
>>>>>>>>> Looking at that vague shape, what's your gut feeling on a price point? 
>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>> We see a couple ways to go with this, curious what your expectations are to start! 
>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>> On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 7:01‚ÄØAM Alex Hillman <alex@indyhall.org <mailto:alex@indyhall.org>> wrote:
>>>>>>>>>> In our case it's solo work that they bring back for peer and teacher feedback. 
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> Our full loop is:
>>>>>>>>>> - 5 minute solo exercise BEFORE they learn the technique, sort of a set up to show them that they need to pay attention. They might get okay results but basically nobody nails it and that's by design. 
>>>>>>>>>> - discuss what went well in that mini exercise, what didn't
>>>>>>>>>> - actual lesson
>>>>>>>>>> - larger full exercise now that they learned it. Usually 10-15 mins of solo work
>>>>>>>>>> - return to class and volunteer for a hot seat where we ask the class for observations about what they see, and then we provide teacher feedback/notes/critique 
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> I imagine a similar loop, if not these specific steps, could def be translated for your stuff!
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 6:46‚ÄØAM Matt Pocock <mattpocockvoice@gmail.com <mailto:mattpocockvoice@gmail.com>> wrote:
>>>>>>>>>>> For more context, here is the vague shape of the workshop I'm planning:
>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>> <image.png>
>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>> On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 11:44‚ÄØAM Matt Pocock <mattpocockvoice@gmail.com <mailto:mattpocockvoice@gmail.com>> wrote:
>>>>>>>>>>>> Yeah, that sounds great. Concretely, what are you giving people during those sessions? Are you saying, "Okay, go into breakout rooms and work in groups to try this out?" Or are you saying, "Let's have five minutes of quiet on the line where we work on these questions individually?" 
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 11:36‚ÄØAM Alex Hillman <alex@indyhall.org <mailto:alex@indyhall.org>> wrote:
>>>>>>>>>>>>> Awesome question - I think there are a few potential answers here but the thing that comes to mind is thinking in terms of "simulations."
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> The thing that most reliability inspires people to try things is seeing them work first hand on small but relatable demos that they can try and report back what worked, what didn't, etc. 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> For example, in 30x500 we have a number of Sales Safari exercises that are really designed less to teach you the mechanics and more to get you actually TRYING it with the goal of seeing the results that make you go "oh I want to apply this to my own XYZ."
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> The things that helped is intentionally choosing examples that are familiar to most but not their domain expertise. 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> The reason here is that people would get in their heads about subtle details and their own biases, and struggle to see the forest for the trees. 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> I think this is a pretty universal challenge when teaching things that are more conceptual like customer research which isn't so much about the mechanics but the practice of getting good at a process that seems simple but packs a lot of power if you use it correctly (which sounds like Ralph too!)
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> In our case that's things like having people do customer research on freelancers or DIY kitchen remodelers or cat owners because even if you aren't that thing, almost everyone knows someone who is so it's not totally foreign conceptually BUT ALSO they aren't bringing all of their own expectations and biases into the exercise as a distraction. 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> We think of these demos as "safe sandboxes" to experiment without feeling attached to the outcome, as compared to if they were starting by working on their own audience where the stakes of getting it wrong were higher. 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> So for Ralph, I'd be thinking about use cases that are in the overlap of "familiar enough to recognize the value" but also "not necessarily something they do every day in their work/life."
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> Giving people those practice examples and instructions to complete, then reflect on what worked and what didn't, is a powerful learning loop that gets people trying, feeling a win, and getting excited to see what that same process looks like on their own thing.
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> Does that make sense and resonate? Any new question it opens up? 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 4:55‚ÄØAM Matt Pocock <mattpocockvoice@gmail.com <mailto:mattpocockvoice@gmail.com>> wrote:

There will still be some interactive exercises and playgrounds, but because Ralph is mostly conceptual, it's going to feel more like I'm inspiring you to try things rather than teaching you APIs.

conversationHistory.body:
Hey all,

One question I had yesterday that slipped my mind was the following:

I'm picturing the Ralph cohort when we get there as slightly less
interactive than previous cohorts. There will still be some interactive
exercises and playgrounds, but because Ralph is mostly conceptual, it's
going to feel more like I'm inspiring you to try things rather than
teaching you APIs.

How does this translate into a live workshop setting? All the live
workshops I've ever done have been extremely practical, where most of the
work is done in small groups, autonomously working through prepared
material.

I have some ideas of my own here, but I would love to get your thoughts -
especially since A&A are experts in this.

Awesome question - I think there are a few potential answers here but the
thing that comes to mind is thinking in terms of "simulations."

The thing that most reliability inspires people to try things is seeing
them work first hand on small but relatable demos that they can try and
report back what worked, what didn't, etc.

For example, in 30x500 we have a number of Sales Safari exercises that are
really designed less to teach you the mechanics and more to get you
actually TRYING it with the goal of seeing the results that make you go "oh
I want to apply this to my own XYZ."

The things that helped is intentionally choosing examples that are familiar
to most but not their domain expertise.

The reason here is that people would get in their heads about subtle
details and their own biases, and struggle to see the forest for the trees.

I think this is a pretty universal challenge when teaching things that are
more conceptual like customer research which isn't so much about the
mechanics but the practice of getting good at a process that seems simple
but packs a lot of power if you use it correctly (which sounds like Ralph
too!)

In our case that's things like having people do customer research on
freelancers or DIY kitchen remodelers or cat owners because even if you
aren't that thing, almost everyone knows someone who is so it's not totally
foreign conceptually BUT ALSO they aren't bringing all of their own
expectations and biases into the exercise as a distraction.

We think of these demos as "safe sandboxes" to experiment without feeling
attached to the outcome, as compared to if they were starting by working on
their own audience where the stakes of getting it wrong were higher.

So for Ralph, I'd be thinking about use cases that are in the overlap of
"familiar enough to recognize the value" but also "not necessarily
something they do every day in their work/life."

Giving people those practice examples and instructions to complete, then
reflect on what worked and what didn't, is a powerful learning loop that
gets people trying, feeling a win, and getting excited to see what that
same process looks like on their own thing.

Does that make sense and resonate? Any new question it opens up?

In our case it's solo work that they bring back for peer and teacher
feedback.

Our full loop is:
- 5 minute solo exercise BEFORE they learn the technique, sort of a set up
to show them that they need to pay attention. They might get okay results
but basically nobody nails it and that's by design.
- discuss what went well in that mini exercise, what didn't
- actual lesson
- larger full exercise now that they learned it. Usually 10-15 mins of solo
work
- return to class and volunteer for a hot seat where we ask the class for
observations about what they see, and then we provide teacher
feedback/notes/critique

I imagine a similar loop, if not these specific steps, could def be
translated for your stuff!

Hey Matt!


The workshop plan sounds good to me. 


A couple things:


We sent our proposal to Joel and we suggest $199-249 for this half-day workshop, but based on your goals you've stated above, we think we should revise that to $99-129. Please don't take this the wrong way, we're not saying it doesn't have the value! 


Think of it as a "doorbuster." Something to lure people in with a no brainer price.


This will help you bring in a wider audience, appeal to many more people than just the ones already super hype about Ralph. Instead of preaching to the crowd, as it were. Somebody who just heard about it will likely open their wallet for $99. Fewer will do it for $199. Very few will do it for $399. 


Since your workshop can support more people, since it won't be very interactive ‚Äî more of a talk, really ‚Äî you don't need to limit seats, and could use this to potentially get lots of people into the habit of buying from you. 


Once somebody's bought from you once, they're very likely to buy from you again!


The other elements to the price are "comparison to your other offerings' price" and "how easy is Ralph to sell?" 


If you price it at $400, that's almost as much as somebody would pay for your week-long cohort, with discounts.


And Ralph is not a big, sweeping thing, general thing, compared to what you teach in those cohorts. Right now, it's very niche. And in our experience so far, selling niche "branches" off the AI tree is not working as well as more general whole project approaches. Makes sense, because the field is still new.


This doesn't close the door on offering a higher-tier Ralph offering later. 


You don't have to add this to your library, even. It could be a one-off special event.


So, especially considering this is a quick launch you want to use to draw in the audience from your appearances, $99-129 is a price that makes an easy sell to the widest audience and will leave people feeling like they got a great value.


Lastly, let's not call it a cohort, which makes it sound like a multi-day course. It's a 1-day workshop. :) 


Amy

‚Äî
Amy Hoy

stackingthebricks.com

>>>>>>>>>> On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 6:46 AM Matt Pocock <mattpocockvoice@gmail.com> wrote:


>>>>>>>>>>> For more context, here is the vague shape of the workshop I'm planning:






>>>>>>>>>>>> On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 11:44 AM Matt Pocock <mattpocockvoice@gmail.com> wrote:


>>>>>>>>>>>>> Yeah, that sounds great. Concretely, what are you giving people during those sessions? Are you saying, "Okay, go into breakout rooms and work in groups to try this out?" Or are you saying, "Let's have five minutes of quiet on the line where we work on these questions individually?" 


>>>>>>>>>>>>>> On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 11:36 AM Alex Hillman <alex@indyhall.org> wrote:


>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Awesome question - I think there are a few potential answers here but the thing that comes to mind is thinking in terms of "simulations."



>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> The thing that most reliability inspires people to try things is seeing them work first hand on small but relatable demos that they can try and report back what worked, what didn't, etc. 



>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> For example, in 30x500 we have a number of Sales Safari exercises that are really designed less to teach you the mechanics and more to get you actually TRYING it with the goal of seeing the results that make you go "oh I want to apply this to my own XYZ."



>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> The things that helped is intentionally choosing examples that are familiar to most but not their domain expertise. 



>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> The reason here is that people would get in their heads about subtle details and their own biases, and struggle to see the forest for the trees. 



>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I think this is a pretty universal challenge when teaching things that are more conceptual like customer research which isn't so much about the mechanics but the practice of getting good at a process that seems simple but packs a lot of power if you use it correctly (which sounds like Ralph too!)



>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> In our case that's things like having people do customer research on freelancers or DIY kitchen remodelers or cat owners because even if you aren't that thing, almost everyone knows someone who is so it's not totally foreign conceptually BUT ALSO they aren't bringing all of their own expectations and biases into the exercise as a distraction. 



>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> We think of these demos as "safe sandboxes" to experiment without feeling attached to the outcome, as compared to if they were starting by working on their own audience where the stakes of getting it wrong were higher. 



>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> So for Ralph, I'd be thinking about use cases that are in the overlap of "familiar enough to recognize the value" but also "not necessarily something they do every day in their work/life."



>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Giving people those practice examples and instructions to complete, then reflect on what worked and what didn't, is a powerful learning loop that gets people trying, feeling a win, and getting excited to see what that same process looks like on their own thing.



>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Does that make sense and resonate? Any new question it opens up?

There will still be some interactive exercises and playgrounds, but because Ralph is mostly conceptual, it's going to feel more like I'm inspiring you to try things rather than teaching you APIs.



>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> How does this translate into a live workshop setting? All the live workshops I've ever done have been extremely practical, where most of the work is done in small groups, autonomously working through prepared material.



>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I have some ideas of my own here, but I would love to get your thoughts - especially since A&A are experts in this.

>>> revise that to $99-129. Please don't take this the wrong way, we're
>>> *not* saying it doesn't have the value!
>>>
>>> Think of it as a "doorbuster." Something to lure people in with a *no
>>> brainer price*.
>>>
>>> This will help you bring in a wider audience, appeal to many more people
>>> than just the ones *already* super hype about Ralph. Instead of
>>> preaching to the crowd, as it were. Somebody who *just heard about it* will
>>> likely open their wallet for $99. Fewer will do it for $199. Very few will
>>> do it for $399.
>>>
>>> Since your workshop can support more people, since it won't be very
>>> interactive ‚Äî more of a talk, really ‚Äî you don't need to limit seats, and
>>> could use this to potentially get lots of people into the habit of buying
>>> from you.
>>>
>>> Once somebody's bought from you once, they're very likely to buy from
>>> you again!
>>>
>>> The other elements to the price are "comparison to your other offerings'
>>> price" and "how easy is Ralph to sell?"
>>>
>>> If you price it at $400, that's almost as much as somebody would pay for
>>> your week-long cohort, with discounts.
>>>
>>> And Ralph is not a big, sweeping thing, general thing, compared to what
>>> you teach in those cohorts. Right now, it's very niche. And in our
>>> experience so far, selling niche "branches" off the AI tree is not working
>>> as well as more general whole project approaches. Makes sense, because the
>>> field is still new.
>>>
>>> This *doesn't* close the door on offering a higher-tier Ralph offering
>>> later.
>>>
>>> You don't *have* to add this to your library, even. It could be a
>>> one-off special event.
>>>
>>> So, especially considering this is a quick launch you want to use to
>>> draw in the audience from your appearances, $99-129 is a price that makes
>>> an easy sell to the widest audience and will leave people feeling like they
>>> got a great value.
>>>
>>> Lastly, let's not call it a cohort, which makes it sound like a
>>> multi-day course. It's a 1-day workshop. :)

>>> Amy

>>>>> On January 14, 2026 at 5:47 PM GMT+1 alex@indyhall.org <mailto:alex@indyhall.org> wrote:
>>>>> 
>>>>> Okay so we're gonna be honest here that there's a very mixed message: 
>>>>> 
>>>>> 1 - On one hand, this is "useful for a lot of people" and the reason to react to it NOW is because of the buzz/attention it's getting and more specifically, that YOU are getting around it. 
>>>>> 
>>>>> 2 - On the other hand, you'd rather a small group and not looking to make a lot of money, happy with 6 people. 
>>>>> 
>>>>> So...which is it? :)
>>>>> 
>>>>> I'm wondering if the Ralph thing is less "good for the business" and more "fun experimental stuff I want to do and maybe has a bigger impact." 
>>>>> 
>>>>> If so, that's fine, let's treat it as such. Maybe having a 4th pillar (in addition to the 3 we mentioned yesterday) of "fun, fully Matt-driven free play experiments that don't need much from the team but recharge his batteries and MAYBE give us advantages for other things."
>>>>> 
>>>>> However if the question is "what's best for the business and by proxy, Matt, your audience, and the team?" then I we need to resolve this contradiction as quickly as possible!
>>>>> 
>>>>> No matter what I think it'd be wise for build in some "free play" - question is if Ralph is that or not? 
>>>>> 
>>>>> On Wed, Jan 14, 2026 at 7:55‚ÄØAM Matt Pocock <mattpocockvoice@gmail.com <mailto:mattpocockvoice@gmail.com>> wrote:
>>>>>> I totally defer to Joel on this. I'm no expert on pricing.
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> I would say that I would actually prefer a smaller group. I don't necessarily want it to devolve into a long workshop because that's more tedious to facilitate and also takes us further away from what the actual workshop will be.
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Not looking to make money out of this workshop. I'd be perfectly happy with six people. Though obviously I can probably facilitate up to 40.
>>>>>>  
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 5:34‚ÄØPM Amy Hoy <team@stackingthebricks.com <mailto:team@stackingthebricks.com>> wrote:
>>>>>>> Hey Matt!
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> The workshop plan sounds good to me. 
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> A couple things:
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> We sent our proposal to Joel and we suggest $199-249 for this half-day workshop, but based on your goals you've stated above, we think we should revise that to $99-129. Please don't take this the wrong way, we're not saying it doesn't have the value! 
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> Think of it as a "doorbuster." Something to lure people in with a no brainer price.
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> This will help you bring in a wider audience, appeal to many more people than just the ones already super hype about Ralph. Instead of preaching to the crowd, as it were. Somebody who just heard about it will likely open their wallet for $99. Fewer will do it for $199. Very few will do it for $399. 
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> Since your workshop can support more people, since it won't be very interactive ‚Äî more of a talk, really ‚Äî you don't need to limit seats, and could use this to potentially get lots of people into the habit of buying from you. 
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> Once somebody's bought from you once, they're very likely to buy from you again!
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> The other elements to the price are "comparison to your other offerings' price" and "how easy is Ralph to sell?" 
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> If you price it at $400, that's almost as much as somebody would pay for your week-long cohort, with discounts.
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> And Ralph is not a big, sweeping thing, general thing, compared to what you teach in those cohorts. Right now, it's very niche. And in our experience so far, selling niche "branches" off the AI tree is not working as well as more general whole project approaches. Makes sense, because the field is still new.
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> This doesn't close the door on offering a higher-tier Ralph offering later. 
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> You don't have to add this to your library, even. It could be a one-off special event.
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> So, especially considering this is a quick launch you want to use to draw in the audience from your appearances, $99-129 is a price that makes an easy sell to the widest audience and will leave people feeling like they got a great value.
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> Lastly, let's not call it a cohort, which makes it sound like a multi-day course. It's a 1-day workshop. :) 
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> Amy
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> ‚Äî
>>>>>>> Amy Hoy
>>>>>>> stackingthebricks.com <http://stackingthebricks.com/>
>>>>>>>> On January 13, 2026 at 6:58 AM MST mattpocockvoice@gmail.com <mailto:mattpocockvoice@gmail.com> wrote:
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Defer to Joel, but probably $400-500?
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 1:08‚ÄØPM Alex Hillman <alex@indyhall.org <mailto:alex@indyhall.org>> wrote:
>>>>>>>>> Looking at that vague shape, what's your gut feeling on a price point? 
>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>> We see a couple ways to go with this, curious what your expectations are to start! 
>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>> On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 7:01‚ÄØAM Alex Hillman <alex@indyhall.org <mailto:alex@indyhall.org>> wrote:
>>>>>>>>>> In our case it's solo work that they bring back for peer and teacher feedback. 
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> Our full loop is:
>>>>>>>>>> - 5 minute solo exercise BEFORE they learn the technique, sort of a set up to show them that they need to pay attention. They might get okay results but basically nobody nails it and that's by design. 
>>>>>>>>>> - discuss what went well in that mini exercise, what didn't
>>>>>>>>>> - actual lesson
>>>>>>>>>> - larger full exercise now that they learned it. Usually 10-15 mins of solo work
>>>>>>>>>> - return to class and volunteer for a hot seat where we ask the class for observations about what they see, and then we provide teacher feedback/notes/critique 
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> I imagine a similar loop, if not these specific steps, could def be translated for your stuff!
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 6:46‚ÄØAM Matt Pocock <mattpocockvoice@gmail.com <mailto:mattpocockvoice@gmail.com>> wrote:
>>>>>>>>>>> For more context, here is the vague shape of the workshop I'm planning:
>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>> <image.png>
>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>> On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 11:44‚ÄØAM Matt Pocock <mattpocockvoice@gmail.com <mailto:mattpocockvoice@gmail.com>> wrote:
>>>>>>>>>>>> Yeah, that sounds great. Concretely, what are you giving people during those sessions? Are you saying, "Okay, go into breakout rooms and work in groups to try this out?" Or are you saying, "Let's have five minutes of quiet on the line where we work on these questions individually?" 
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 11:36‚ÄØAM Alex Hillman <alex@indyhall.org <mailto:alex@indyhall.org>> wrote:
>>>>>>>>>>>>> Awesome question - I think there are a few potential answers here but the thing that comes to mind is thinking in terms of "simulations."
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> The thing that most reliability inspires people to try things is seeing them work first hand on small but relatable demos that they can try and report back what worked, what didn't, etc. 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> For example, in 30x500 we have a number of Sales Safari exercises that are really designed less to teach you the mechanics and more to get you actually TRYING it with the goal of seeing the results that make you go "oh I want to apply this to my own XYZ."
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> The things that helped is intentionally choosing examples that are familiar to most but not their domain expertise. 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> The reason here is that people would get in their heads about subtle details and their own biases, and struggle to see the forest for the trees. 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> I think this is a pretty universal challenge when teaching things that are more conceptual like customer research which isn't so much about the mechanics but the practice of getting good at a process that seems simple but packs a lot of power if you use it correctly (which sounds like Ralph too!)
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> In our case that's things like having people do customer research on freelancers or DIY kitchen remodelers or cat owners because even if you aren't that thing, almost everyone knows someone who is so it's not totally foreign conceptually BUT ALSO they aren't bringing all of their own expectations and biases into the exercise as a distraction. 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> We think of these demos as "safe sandboxes" to experiment without feeling attached to the outcome, as compared to if they were starting by working on their own audience where the stakes of getting it wrong were higher. 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> So for Ralph, I'd be thinking about use cases that are in the overlap of "familiar enough to recognize the value" but also "not necessarily something they do every day in their work/life."
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> Giving people those practice examples and instructions to complete, then reflect on what worked and what didn't, is a powerful learning loop that gets people trying, feeling a win, and getting excited to see what that same process looks like on their own thing.
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> Does that make sense and resonate? Any new question it opens up? 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>> On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 4:55‚ÄØAM Matt Pocock <mattpocockvoice@gmail.com <mailto:mattpocockvoice@gmail.com>> wrote:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Hey all,
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>  
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> One question I had yesterday that slipped my mind was the following:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I'm picturing the Ralph cohort when we get there as slightly less interactive than previous cohorts. There will still be some interactive exercises and playgrounds, but because Ralph is mostly conceptual, it's going to feel more like I'm inspiring you to try things rather than teaching you APIs.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> How does this translate into a live workshop setting? All the live workshops I've ever done have been extremely practical, where most of the work is done in small groups, autonomously working through prepared material.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I have some ideas of my own here, but I would love to get your thoughts - especially since A&A are experts in this.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

subject: Re: A quick question...

triggerMessage.subject: Re: A quick question...
triggerMessage.body:
Hi Matt,

Thanks for reaching out. I'm like you also was a part of the TS world for a
long time. Now time has changed and I feel like I'm getting behind with all
AI innovations.
There are a few areas that interest me about AI:

   - Product development - how can AI models/agents/workflows enhance my
   product, how can I make users life easier.
   - Software development lifecycle - how can AI help me to write better
   code and deliver better product features.

I think, in more general terms, I'm interested in understanding how to
design and build AI flows, be it agents or workflows. I'm also interested
in learning how to assess different models to be able to choose one that
suits the use-case best.

I hope it helps.

Cheers,
Anton

subject: AI is so confusing, where do i start?

triggerMessage.subject: Re: AI is so confusing, where do i start?
triggerMessage.body:
The knowledge base isn't returning results, but here's what I'd suggest: Start with the fundamentals section in AI Hero. It covers core concepts like how AI models work, prompt engineering basics, and common use cases. Work through one module at a time rather than trying to absorb everything at once.
What specific part of AI are you most interested in - the theory side, practical applications, or something else?

subject: Proposal Investment

triggerMessage.subject: Proposal Investment
triggerMessage.body:
Hi Dear, 
 My name is Brayan Parker, and I'm taking the liberty of contacting you about your project, for which I've identified potential interest on the part of our network of investors.  I would therefore like to know if you are currently looking for financing. 
 I represent an asset management company specializing in project financing.  
 We have a strong and diversified investor portfolio, including business angels, family offices and venture capital (VC) funds.  We can intervene in the form of credit or equity, with a minimum entry ticket of ‚Ç¨300,000. 
 If you are in the process of raising funds, please do not hesitate to contact me so that we can discuss your project in greater detail. I'd also be delighted to provide you with more information about our company and the investor profiles we support. 
 Best Regards, Brayan Parker Our website:  https://diagram-investments.com

subject: Re: A quick question...

triggerMessage.subject: Re: A quick question...
triggerMessage.body:
Hey Matt,

Thanks for reaching out. I've been following your TypeScript work for a
while now.

Regarding AI, there is obviously a lot of reasonable hype right now, but
social media is saturated with rage-bait, exaggerations, and people
misrepresenting what's actually possible just for engagement.

I'm mostly interested in cutting through that noise to find clear,
grounded, and true perspectives on what is really happening in the AI
coding space.

Best,
Javier
